results.title: Marlon Brando
results.creator_credit: Claudio Masenza, Donatella Baglivo and Ciak Studio
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hollywood’s rebels”.
This documentary highlights the experiences of those that worked with Marlon Brando, whether cast or crew, throughout his career, and provides a unique insight into the man himself. Director Claudio Masenza has collated a myriad of interviews from colleagues, friends and family, as well as stills and film clips to give a thorough overview of Brando’s acting career, and although much praise is bestowed on the star the rebellious presence of Brando on the Hollywood stage is also discussed. Candid accounts and anecdotes make up this portrayal of Brando’s darker side in tandem with a sensitive discussion of the talent that made Brando one of the most sought after actors in Hollywood following his debut in the 1950s.

results.title: Monkey on the back
results.creator_credit: Julian Biggs, Grant McLean and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This documentary drama, based on the real-life experiences of a drug addict, not only portrays the terrible consequences of the misuse of narcotics but presents the general problem of addiction and, particularly, of the addict as an individual. Dick Smith lost everything valued most in life because of his craving for the narcotics which finally killed him. In relating the story of his attempts to break the habit, the film reveals the essential nature of addiction as both a social and a human problem.

results.title: James Baldwin: the price of the ticket
results.creator_credit: Karen Thorsen, Douglas Dempsey and William Miles
results.brief_description: The life, works and beliefs of the late Black American writer and civil- rights activist, James Baldwin; what it is to be born black, impoverished, gay and gifted in a world that has as yet to understand that “all men are brothers”. In this documentary without narration, Baldwin tells his own story. Using rarely-seen archival footage the film melds intimate interviews and eloquent public speeches with astounding cinema-verite glimpses of James Baldwin. An emotional portrait, a social critique and a passionate plea for human equality.

results.title: Monkey Grip
results.creator_credit: Ken Cameron, Patricia Lovell and Pavilion Films
results.brief_description: Explores the joys and traumas of a group of people living in Melbourne’s inner-city. Revolving around the life of a single mother sharing a communal house, the film portrays the lives of talented and reckless artists who refuse to live by the conventional rules.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Cameron, Patricia Lovell and Pavilion Films
results.description:
Explores the joys and traumas of a group of people living in Melbourne’s inner-city in the early 1980s. Revolving around the life of a single mother sharing a communal house, the film portrays the lives of talented and reckless musicians, actors and writers who refuse to live by the conventional rules. Noni Hazelhurst received an AFI Best Actress Award for her performance in 1982.

Starring Noni Hazelhurst, Colin Friels, Harold Hopkins, Candy Raymond, Michael Caton, Tim Burns, Cathy Downes, Lisa Peers, Din Miller-Robinson, Alice Garner and Christina Amphlett from the ‘Divinyls’. Adapted from Helen Garner’s novel ‘Monkey Grip’ by Ken Cameron in association with Helen Garner. Cinematography by David Gribble. Editing by David Huggett.
description_for_label:

Revolving around the life of a single mother sharing a communal house, the film portrays the lives of talented and reckless musicians, actors and writers who refuse to live by the conventional rules. Noni Hazelhurst received an AFI Best Actress Award for her performance in 1982.

Starring Noni Hazelhurst, Colin Friels, Harold Hopkins, Candy Raymond, Michael Caton, Tim Burns, Cathy Downes, Lisa Peers, Din Miller-Robinson, Alice Garner and Christina Amphlett from the ‘Divinyls’. Adapted from Helen Garner’s novel ‘Monkey Grip’ by Ken Cameron in association with Helen Garner. Cinematography by David Gribble. Editing by David Huggett.

results.title: Monica's seaside adventures
results.creator_credit: Ignatius Jones, Monica Trapaga and Monica and the Moochers
results.brief_description: A feast of summery beach songs designed to get small children toe-tapping and dancing. Monica’s crazy friends include Ted, McKaw, Compost bin, Fridge and Dr. Wango Tango. Bring your bathers and groove to the “Beach Boogaloo”, make waves at the “Sand Crab’s Disco” and learn “‘Sid Shark’s Step”.

results.title: Monica Goermann: gymnast
results.creator_credit: Steven Keller, Jacques Bobet and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Monica Goermann is a young Winipeg gymnast who is on her way to becoming an international celebrity. Under the watchful supervision of her mother, who is also her coach, Monica trains daily, executing difficult moves with superhuman control. In this film she is shown preparing for the 1978 Commonwealth Games at Edmonton, where she tied for the Siver Medal.

results.title: McLuhan's wake
results.creator_credit: Kevin McMahon, Kristina McLaughlin, Michael McMahon, National Film Board of Canada and Primitive Entertainment
results.brief_description: Formally innovative documentary about the ideas and life of Marshall McLuhan, one of the most enigmatic and provocative thinkers about technology and culture in the twentieth century. Fascinated by the role technology played in transforming our lives, McLuhan predicted, with stunning accuracy, the impact the digital age would have on our social, spiritual, economic and ideological selves. He called for a science of media ecology to escape the powerful effects of the media. He also pioneered the idea of inter-disciplinary and media studies within the university, heading the newly opened Center for Culture and Technology at the University of Toronto in 1967. McLuhan publicised his theories with deliberately provocative appearances on TV, a strategy that bought him celebrity but lessened his credibility in the eyes of his academic colleges. When he died in 1980 - the same year CNN began and IBM created the first personal computer - he had largely lost his audience. Grounded in McLuhan’s last scholarly work, ‘The Laws of Media’, the film translates the four laws he proposed into an illuminating and revealing text, haunted by archival footage and the voice of McLuhan himself. Blending all forms of media, including animation and special effects, ‘McLuhan’s Wake’ is a visually dazzling and poetic film, with narration by renowned performance artist Laurie Anderson, and commentary by scholars Eric McLuhan, Neil Postman, Lewis Lapham and journalist Patrick Watson. An educator’s resource guide is available at http://www.nfb.ca/mcluhanswake/film.html

results.title: McFeast: breasts
results.creator_credit: Damian Davis, Mark Fitzgerald and ABC
results.brief_description: Elle McFeast, (Lisbeth Gorr) with cohorts, Mark Warren, Mikey Robins and John Hinde explore the issue of breasts. A joyous celebration of women and their bodies. A host of stars including Kate Ceberano and Kate Fischer, as well as comments from people on the street, discuss the issue of cleavage in an unexploitative way.

results.title: Mcbus
results.creator_credit: Derek May, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is a “nowhere tour” of Montreal, a sort of parody of the world we live in, where all is confusion, aimlessness and noise. A recurring figure in the film is a Highland piper walking his beat on a lonely patch of ground beneath an elevated highway. The busload of sightseers encounters him as they do other objects of curiosity. At one point, the tour guide, a young woman, and the piper have a fling at dancing. It is a bus tour where everything is unexpected. Cast includes Don Ares, Cheryl Davis, Ron Sutherland. Photography by Thomas Vamos. Edited by Donald Rennick. Sound by Ted Haley, Claude Hazanavicius, Victor Merrill.

results.title: Women of the sun
results.creator_credit: Bob Weis, Channel 0\28 and Generation Films
results.brief_description: A series of four dramas each of which focuses on the story of one Aboriginal woman at different stages of the history of white Australia, to illustrate some of the injustices which have been inflicted on the Aboriginals in the past.
